Daily report: [2019-01-17 Thu]

TODO Headline Time
ALL Total time 4:23
File time 4:23
Today’s Tasks 3:16
TODO   CS5001 0:50
DONE     Prepare CS5001 homework for submission 0:50
TODO   CS5002 1:41
DONE     Prepare CS5002 homework for submission 1:41
WAITING   Apply for GradPlus loans for 2019-2020 0:42
DONE   Send email to MD about financial aid 0:03
Morning Ritual 1:07
TODO   Meditation 0:11
TODO   Shower 0:23
TODO   Breakfast 0:33

Summary

I finalized the submission of my first homework assignment for both of my classes. Dedicated time to finalizing financial aid and reviewing for today’s lab session.

Problem

For CS5001, I allocated some time this morning making sure style was correct, test cases, and generally good for submission. A good chunk of time trying to setup latex to play nicely with emacs. I was able to get it working but couldn’t get the completion engine, company, to work with the latex symbols. I’m going to try this again at some point in the future so I’m able to submit my homework assignments digitally. I experienced some difficulty with the financial aid office and I’m waiting to hear back.

Insight

To start homework assignments earlier and focus on completing them. I will start using emacs to calculate the amount of effort it takes to complete a given task.

Doing Despite Disliking: Self-regulatory Strategies in Everyday Aversive Activities

Abstract: We investigated the self-regulatory strategies people spontaneously use in their everyday lives to regulate their persistence during aversive activities. In pilot studies (pooled N = 794), we identified self-regulatory strategies from self-reports and generated hypotheses about individual differences in trait self-control predicting their use. Next, deploying ambulatory assessment (N = 264, 1940 reports of aversive/challenging activities), we investigated predictors of the strategies’self-reported use and effectiveness (trait self-control and demand types). The popularity of strategies varied across demands. In addition, people higher in trait self-control were more likely to focus on the positive consequences of a given activity, set goals, and use emotion regulation. Focusing on positive consequences, focusing on negative consequences (of not performing the activity), thinking of the near finish, and emotion regulation increased perceived self-regulatory success across demands, whereas distracting oneself from the aversive activity decreased it. None of these strategies, however, accounted for the beneficial effects of trait self-control on perceived self-regulatory success. Hence, trait self-control and strategy use appear to represent separate routes to good self-regulation. By considering trait- and process-approaches these findings promote a more comprehensive understanding of self-regulatory success and failure during people’s daily attempts to regulate their persistence. © 2018 European Association of Personality Psychology

Tomorrow

To review this week’s material from both CS5001 and CS5001 classes and to marinate the homework released for each class.

Completed Tasks
